Issues.Title: XAML {x:Static FooClass.Border} will be compiled unexpectedly to {x:Static SystemParameters.Border}
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview5
* Windows version: 10.0.18895.1000
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes

 <!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->
 
 **Problem description:**

When assigning a WPF dependency property using `x:Static` markup extension and pass a CLR property named `Border` into it, the XAML compiler will compile this static property to `SystemParameters.Border` which is not expected.

 **Actual behavior:**

This first one will be compiled to the second.

```xml
<!-- The original code -->
<Button Content="{x:Static local:FooClass.Border}" />
```

```xml
<!-- The compiled code -->
<Button Content="{x:Static SystemParameters.Border}" />
```

 **Expected behavior:**

XAML compiler should not change the original property assigning of `x:Static` markup extension.
 
 **Minimal repro:**
 
1. Create a WPF (.NET Core / .NET Framework) project;
1. Write a class with a static property named `Border`;
1. Write a `x:Static` usage in a XAML file.

You can view the minimal reproduction on my GitHub project here:

- [walterlv/XamlBugs.StaticProperties](https://github.com/walterlv/XamlBugs.StaticProperties)

The key codes are here:

```csharp
// This namespace can be changed to any other and the bug still reproduces.
namespace XamlBugs.StaticProperties
{
    /// <summary>
    /// The class that provide a `Border` property.
    /// You can change this class name to any other and the bug still reproduces.
    /// </summary>
    public static class FooClass
    {
        /// <summary>
        /// The correct value for this property is `string.Empty`, but you'll see `1` in actual.
        /// </summary>
        public static string Border => "";
    }
}
```

```xml
<Window x:Class="XamlBugs.StaticProperties.MainWindow"
        xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
        xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
        xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
        xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
        xmlns:local="clr-namespace:XamlBugs.StaticProperties"
        mc:Ignorable="d"
        Title="MainWindow" Height="450" Width="800">
    <Grid>

        <!-- When you run this application, and you'll see an incorrect content value of this `Button`.
             If you try to decompile this assembly and view the mainwindow.baml file,
             you'll find that the static value has been changed to `SystemParameters.Border` -->
        <!-- The XAML namespace prefix can be changed to any other and the bug still reproduces. -->
        <Button Content="{x:Static local:FooClass.Border}" />

        <!-- Don't uncomment this line, because it will cause a runtime error.
             The `FooClass.Border` property is a string,
             but it will be compiled to `SystemParameters.Border` which is not a string. -->
        <!--<TextBlock Text="{x:Static local:FooClass.Border}" />-->
        
    </Grid>
</Window>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "XAML {x:Static FooClass.Border} will be compiled unexpectedly to {x:Static SystemParameters.Border}" (#679)

Issues.Title: Re-enable T4 generation in build
Issues.Body:
There's a bug in the VisualStudio T4 text engine that causes CI and local builds to fail. We will need to either wait for 16.1 Preview4, or add a reference to Newtonsoft.Json ourselves to unblock ourselves and then remove the following lines from PresentationCore.csproj, WindowsBase.csproj, and PresentationFramework.csproj:

`<!-- <Import Project="$(WpfCodeGenDir)DesignTimeTextTemplating.targets" /> -->`

Other option is to convert to using mono/t4
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Re-enable T4 generation in build" (#674)

Issues.Title: WPF Surface 2.0 SDK Source Code
Issues.Body:
Given that much of the WPF Surface 2.0 SDK is both usable and useful when developing WPF .Net 4.x applications, it would be great to see the WPF Surface 2.0 SDK published as open source.  Unlike the rest of the WPF sources, this could be done independently and immediately and would provide significant value to the community from day 1.

If nothing else, publish the source to ScatterView!

Thus, Microsoft could leave it to the community to integrate this work with the eventual .Net Standard 3.0 implementation of WPF.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WPF Surface 2.0 SDK Source Code" (#673)

Issues.Title: [3.0 preview 4/5] Windows 10 (1809) DPI size not working for WPF application
Issues.Body:
The selected DPI size under Windows 10 is not working for WPF applications,
the WPF application use always a 100% DPI scale.

Tested with:
* SDK 3.0.100-preview3-010431 - Working 
* SDK 3.0.100-preview4-011223 - Not working 
* SDK 3.0.100-preview5-011568 - Not working
* All from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.0

System:
* Windows 10 - 1809 (Build 17763.437)
* DPI: 125%
* Resolution: 1920 x 1200
* Visual Studio 2019 - Version 16.1.0 Preview 3.0
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[3.0 preview 4/5] Windows 10 (1809) DPI size not working for WPF application" (#668)

Issues.Title: VB WPF .NET Core 3.0 missing from New Project dialog
Issues.Body:
I have the ability to create a new C# WPF .NET core project, but not a Visual Basic project. 

(Using Visual Studio 2019 latest preview and .NET core 3.0 preview 5)

/cc @rladuca
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "VB WPF .NET Core 3.0 missing from New Project dialog" (#667)

Issues.Title: .NET Core 3.0 WPF Crash when copying from RichTextBox
Issues.Body:
@OliveOil1 commented on [Wed Apr 03 2019](https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk/issues/1185)

Copying from a RichTextBox control in .NET Core 3.0 with WPF will consistently cause the application to freeze up and eventually crash. This problem only seems to affect RichTextBoxs, as when I tried with a regular TextBox, it ran perfectly fine.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".NET Core 3.0 WPF Crash when copying from RichTextBox" (#664)

Issues.Title: Fix ResX Code Generation
Issues.Body:
Due to a change in Arcade in GenerateResxSource.targets, we need to set GenerateResxSource to true so that codegen runs on our EmbeddedResources.  This is blocking some DARC PRs with the latest Arcade changes.

fixes #662
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix ResX Code Generation" (#663)

Issues.Title: Fix ResX code generation due to changes in Arcade
Issues.Body:
Latest Arcade changes in https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/tree/darc-master-154bfb93-0564-405e-88b9-df2489fd6e99 caused ResX code generation to break.

This results in missing SR code files and is blocking DARC PRs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Fix ResX code generation due to changes in Arcade" (#662)

Issues.Title: XAML/Codebehind icons in VS2019 Solution Explorer are different: Framework vs. Core
Issues.Body: * .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview5 * Windows version: 18362.53 * Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: It's a difference in solution explorer between Framework and Core. Maybe this bug is related to Visual Studio, or WPF integration in Visual Studio. **Problem description:** Create a WPF project in VS2019 with .NET Core, and create one with .NET Framework. The icons for XAML files and Codebehind files look different **Actual behavior:** It looks like this in VS2019 16.1 Preview 3. Note the different icons for XAML and C# files between the two WPF projects: In VS2019 16.0.3 it looks like this: **Expected behavior:** Icons should be the same for WPF on Core and Framework
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "XAML/Codebehind icons in VS2019 Solution Explorer are different: Framework vs. Core" (#661)

Issues.Title: Add an markup extension to bind standard values of a type
Issues.Body:
A long time ago I wrote [Enumerate](https://github.com/YohDeadfall/Enumerate) which is designed to provide standard values of any type if it supports it. It's used mostly for `enum`s, but as I said it isn't limited to them. And because WPF is open source now, I think it's time to make the markup extension built-in so everyone will be able to use out of the box.

## Features

1. Providing values of an `enum` as is.
2. Providing values of an `enum` from `DescriptionAttribute`s.
1. Providing values of any type whose `TypeConverter` returns the standard values via the `GetStandardValues` method.

## Usage:

```csharp

public enum ViewModelStatus
{
    [Description("Offen")]
    Open,
    [Description("Geschlossen")]
    Closed,
    [Description("In Arbeit")]
    InProgress
}

public class ViewModel : INotifyPropertyChanged
{
    public ViewModelStatus Status { get; set; }
}

```

```xaml
<ComboBox ItemsSource="{e:Enumerate {x:Type local:ViewModelStatus}, Converter={StaticResource EnumToStringConverter}}"
          SelectedItem="{Binding Status, Converter={StaticResource EnumToStringConverter}}" />
<!-- ItemsSource will contain Offen, Geschlossen and In Arbeit -->
```

---

Related to #455.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add an markup extension to bind standard values of a type" (#655)

Issues.Title: RichTextBox does not display numeric multilevel lists (1.1, 1.2, 1.2.1 etc) in rtf files correctly.
Issues.Body:
When you load the attached "example.rtf" file into a System.Windows.Control.RichTextBox using richTextBox.Selection.Load(File.OpenRead("..\\..\\example.rtf"), DataFormats.Rtf); the multilevel numeric list is not displayed correctly. The Major numbers of the list items are missing. See "RichTextBoxNumericListsError.PNG" for an example. However, the System.Windows.Forms.RichTextBox correctly displays the list item numbering. See "FormsRichTextBoxCorrect.PNG" for an example. _This issue has been moved from https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/491250/richtextbox-does-not-display-numeric-multilevel-li.html VSTS ticketId: 821847_ _These are the original issue comments:_ Visual Studio Feedback System on 3/17/2019, 11:59 PM (46 days ago):

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

_These are the original issue solutions:_ (no solutions)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "RichTextBox does not display numeric multilevel lists (1.1, 1.2, 1.2.1 etc) in rtf files correctly." (#650)
